RMP MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE:  Operation, safety, and environmental issues must be reviewed prior to initiation of a process change to ensure that they do not compromise the operational safety and integrity of the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, and to minimize adverse effects to worker safety and public health. The Facility RMP Management of Change (MOC) procedures are used to evaluate all changes to process materials, controls, equipment, and procedures. The MOC procedures were last modified on September 14, 2020.

PRE START-UP SAFETY REVIEW:  The pre start-up safety review (PSSR) applies to additions or modifications to the Anhydrous Ammonia Process that require the safety information to be revised or updated. Whenever changes in affected processes are identified or planned, they must be evaluated as to the need for a pre start-up safety review. This assessment is undertaken in conjunction with the MOC review. Additionally, a pre start-up safety review is performed in conjunction with the MOC review when the proposed change requires modifications to the safety procedures. The most recent change that required a PSSR occurred in 2015, and the PSSR was completed on August 5, 2015.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS:  Periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan must be conducted every three years. Records of the audits and follow-up documentation are maintained to indicate findings and resolution of findings. The most recent compliance audit was conducted on April 25, 2019.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION:  Although no incidents involving regulated substances have occurred at the Facility in the last five years, an incident investigation program is in place. The program includes investigation requirements and reporting and would be implemented

in the event of an incident.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION:  The Facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations. The Walnut Grove has an Employee Participation Program in place and has implemented procedures regarding engaging employees for their input, as well as ensuring access to safety documentation to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program. The Employee Participation procedures were last modified on September 22, 2020.

HOT WORK PERMIT:  With regard to hot work that may occur on or near the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, Grow West has developed a written Hot Work Permit program and procedure to document the evaluation of the fire prevention and protection requirements. The Hot Work Permit procedure was last updated on March 18, 2019.

CONTRACTOR SAFETY:  The contractors used by the Facility for anhydrous ammonia delivery have been informed regarding the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to delivery of anhydrous ammonia to the Grow West Walnut Grove. The Facility has confirmed that the delivery contractors have provided the appropriate training to their drivers regarding the delivery of anhydrous ammonia. Grow West Walnut Grove also qualifies contractors who are engaged in maintaining the RS systems to ensure that equipment is modified or repaired and returned to service safely. Contractor Safety procedure was last updated on March 18, 2019.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

ES-1.0  FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY

The owners, management, and employees of the Walnut Grove Retail, part of Grow West (herein referred to as Walnut Grove or the Walnut Grove Facility) at 14301 Railroad Ave, Walnut Grove, California 95690 are committed to the prevention of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. A detailed Emergency Action Plan - Consolidated Contingency Plan (EAP CCP) has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.


ES-2.0  FACILITY INFORMATION

The Facility is a retail agricultural facility whose primary activity is the storage and sale of fertilizers in addition to the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to agricultural operations in the Sacramento Delta Area of Northern California. Applicable NAICS codes for this facility include 42491 (Farm Supplies Merchant Wholesalers).

*- Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as crop production nutrients. 
*- Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored in a 14,323 gallon storage tank (bullet).
*- The anhydrous ammonia storage vessels are filled to no more than 85% of shell volume. 

ANHYDROUS AMMONIA BULLET 
* - Vessel Capacity: 14,323 gals
* - Maximum Amount of NH3: 12,175 gals
* - Mass of NH3: 62,580 lbs

The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled is 62,580 pounds.

ES-4.0  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia during the last five years resulting in death, injuries, evacuation(s), a shelter in-place order, or property or environmental damage.


ES-5.0  THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The facility's emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan requirements. The facility also developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) in accordance with the requirements presented in the CalARP regulations §2745.8. The Emergency Action Plan - Consolidated Contingency Plan (EAP-CCP) was most recently updated on August 1, 2018 and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.


ES-6.0  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Safety improvement is an on-going process at the Facility. Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Specific changes to the anhydrous ammonia process at the Facility will be implemented as needed.

HAZARD REVIEW:  A hazard review of the anhydrous ammonia process is conducted every five years or as needed by changes in the processes. The most recent update of the hazard review for the anhydrous ammonia process was conducted on February 27, 2020. Results indicate that no high-risk hazards were identified through the hazard review updates.

OPERATING PROCEDURES:  Written standard operating procedures have been developed for the covered processes and are reviewed and revised as needed. The operating procedures were last revised on September 16, 2020. Operating procedures for the Anhydrous Ammonia Process are certified annually, with the last annual certification on Operating procedures for the Anhydrous Ammonia Process are certified annually, with the last annual certification on September 16, 2020. 

TRAINING:  The Walnut Grove Retail Facility staff, as well as Grow West corporate staff, understands that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program. The training program was last reviewed on October 01, 2018. 

The current training program is comprised of the following:
  1.  Initial employee training;
  2.  Periodic refresher training;
  3.  Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification;
  4.  Competency testing involving written tests and observation following training; and
  5.  Training records for each employee.
